awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Structural Constraints on Microcontinent Formation, Gulf of California
awd_abstract_narration:
When a continent rifts apart to form a new ocean basin, sometimes it breaks into two big pieces and a few smaller pieces called microcontinents.  Microcontinents form early in the history of rifting, and afterwards they stay on one side of the rift, sink below sea level, and are buried by younger oceanic sedimentation. It is important to understand the development of microcontinent boundaries because these boundaries may host mineral deposits and hydrocarbons. We will do a field geology study of a young microcontinent that is above sea level, still actively forming, and bordered on two sides by active faults. We will test different models for the fault patterns and the timing of the uplift that caused its development. The field data we need to collect include: geological mapping of active faults; detailed study of elevations and ages of terraces that are offset by the faults; and mapping and sampling of nearby volcanic rocks to see if the volcanism was related to the rifting in terms of age or composition. Our study will help scientists to understand other, older microcontinents that are important in resource exploration, but are now buried by sediments and accessible only by drilling. Our team of investigators includes two female professors from the USA with their students, and collaborators from a Mexican research institute.  During this study, we will train two graduate students in state-of-the art geological techniques including structure-from-motion, luminescence and/or cosmogenic radionuclide dating. This project will strengthen the international collaboration among the three institutions and train the graduate students in international field work. Research results will be incorporated into outreach activities including Spanish-language TV news interviews, annual teacher training workshops, an informational public display at Caltech, and public outreach events at UCLA. 



Multiple models have been proposed to explain microcontinent isolation in strike-slip settings. To test these models, we will examine the structures of a newly isolated, subaerial microcontinent of Isla Angel de la Guarda (IAG) in the northern Gulf of California. The IAG lies along the Pacific-North America plate boundary, and its southern tip contains a dense array of young continental faults. These cut a set of marine terraces within 20 km of a well-developed transform fault, along strike from a nascent spreading center. We will evaluate how the faults on IAG may be geometrically connected to the currently active plate boundary faults in the Ballenas Transform system as well as to former plate boundary faults in the Tiburon Basin to the SE of the island. We will constrain the timing and kinematics of the IAG faults through detailed geologic and structural mapping, topographic analysis using high resolution digital elevation mapping, and dating of geomorphic surfaces. During yearly field trips we will map bedrock types, fault geometry and structures, and geomorphic surface deformation, and collect samples for dating of bedrock, marine terraces, alluvial fans, and fault zones. Geological field work and image processing will be conducted jointly by researchers and students from Caltech, UCLA, and CICESE (Ensenada, Mexico). Samples collected in years 1 and 2 for dating geomorphic surfaces will be processed at UCLA using luminescence and/or cosmogenic radionuclide dating techniques. Bedrock samples will be geochemically analyzed at Caltech and dated by CICESE. The results of this study can transform our understanding of the early development of microcontinents, and our approach can be applicable to other microcontinents in the Atlantic, Indian, and Arctic oceans that have been targeted for resource exploration.

por.por_cntn:
We studied the development of a newly isolated subaerial microcontinent as an example of the general problem of microcontinent formation during plate tectonic rifting and development of ocean basins. The block we studied is an uninhabited island: Isla Angel de la Guarda (IAG) in the northern Gulf of California. This is a continental block surrounded by ocean basins.  It was originally attached to Baja California, Mexico, prior to the development of the strike-slip fault and basin system that separated this block from the Baja California Peninsula as part of the motion between the Pacific Plate on the west and the North America plate on the east. Our studies included field expeditions on the island during 2017 to 2019, in which we made maps of the volcanic rocks and sedimentary units, mapped and measured the faults that cut the area, conducted high resolution mapping of the topography using a drone, and collected samples to take back to the lab for geochemical and age studies.  Our collaborators at UCLA conducted dating of the surfaces of terraces that were cut by the faults, and we conducted geochemical analysis and obtained ages for the volcanic rocks beneath the terraces.

We collected 77 rock samples.  The data for these locations was entered in the IEDA SESAR sample database. Selected rock samples were used for geochemical analysis and for age dating.  The geochemistry, done by the technique of X-Ray Fluorescence, shows that the lavas range in composition from basaltic andesite to rhyolite. Most of those samples are andesite and dacite. Their major and trace element geochemistry shows that they are similar to continental rocks and not similar to lavas that erupt at mid ocean ridges or at subduction-related volcanic arcs.

40Ar/39Ar geochronology shows that the lava flows range in age from 3.9 Ma (Millions of years) to 2.75 Ma. This is important to establish the history of volcanism around this plate boundary. We tested a correlation between these lava flows and the Puertecitos volcanic province, which is nearby on the Baja California Peninsula. However, the IAG lava flows are slightly younger and of a different composition than the rocks found in the Puertecitos volcanic province.

We mapped at least three generations of extensive, non-marine terraces, distinguished by differences in elevation and surface roughness. With satellite imagery, drone-based DEMs, and field geology, we mapped several sub-parallel, NNE-striking normal faults that cut the terraces and volcanic flows. Fault motion is dominantly down-to-the-east with <100 m of total offset per fault. A few faults show evidence for dextral motion. Our results indicate that IAG is actively accommodating extensional strain adjacent to the Ballenas transform fault zone to the west.  The faulting on the island may be connected to the active faults underwater  along this plate boundary transform fault in the Ballenas Channel.

This project supported the PHD studies of one female graduate student at Caltech, and two other female graduate students at Caltech who collaborated on the project and participated in the data analysis. One of the graduate students mentored an undergraduate summer researcher during the initial phase of the study. These students worked in an international collaborative team with researchers from academic institutions from both the United States and Mexico, as well as government scientists.  This helped them to learn how to conduct productive international collaborations in their future work and gave them examples of how to integrate their science into outreach activities for younger students and the general public.

We collborated on 5 peer-reviewed journal articles as part of this project.


Last Modified: 01/12/2024
Modified by: Joann M Stock
